review_title: Overall a great place to work
pros: Schedule is very flexible, manager was great, lots of team work, very strong support for work-life balance.
cons: Health insurance is really expensive and not a lot of options.

review_title: Former physician is concerned about the clinic's future
pros: Staff tried hard to care for patients in a challenging environment
cons: Top leadership has made a series of poor decisions leading to steady decline in morale and departure of many talented physicians, nurses, and other staff members that are critical for maintaining an environment that provides quality care.

pros: Providers were great and were great with patients, benefits are okay
cons: System is horrible, very short staffed, you were lucky if you could take PTO, upper management makes decisions but never comes to the buildings, many times you are working two departments and the training is awful. Also operation managers are a joke inside the clinic.

pros: Easy, mind-numbing work. Information Services team is generally easy to work with.
cons: Leadership is lacking, company culture is a joke, former CEO was a laughing stock, current C-level suite almost bankrupt the entire clinic. There is an upcoming merger with another company, the product will most likely be a management and IT help desk total replacement. After 1 year of working here I have learned something poor and disappointing every week and I am still surprised I can be let down at this point. Lastly many people in healthcare act entitled and envious. Imagine "my manager's manager has three monitors why don't I as a basic nurse."

pros: Money is good, overtime is every now and then.
cons: Poor management.Disrespect to employees. Management changes policies as they feel. Very poor morale due to management.

review_title: Not what it use to be
job_title: Certified Medical Assistant (CMA) in Eau Claire, WI
pros: The people you work with, In general your co workers are good
cons: The management is lacking, They think that everyone is replaceable and do not want to listen to anyone. They have let so many good employees out the door that no one is coming in the door anymore

pros: Some great people to work with.
cons: Pay, time off, management thinking they know what your doing when they are never in your area, pick favorites

pros: It is funny how, while a vast majority of the people working there are good people, interested in making a living while being of service for others, a small minority of "elites" or "directors" or "managers" are about to succeed reducing the whole system to rubble.
cons: The entire board of directors is populated with idiots, impotent caricatures. The ceo who was supposed to be fired and investigated for inappropriate doings eventually resigned, but actually did not resign right away - she will spend one more year here driving the whole system into the ground, while collecting a couple more millions of dollars. Her leave will not change much tough for a new class o future "leaders" of even worse quality is groomed, or should I say a new caste?

pros: Their checks still clear so that's nice.
cons: Backwards thinking and disorganized. They do not adhere to basic fundamentals and best practices for financial matters.

job_title: Certified Ophthalmic Assistant in Beaver Dam, WI

cons: understaffed. employees are overworked and underpaid

review_title: It Starts at the Top - Management Sucks
pros: My works hours were great
cons:
The HR department is not there to assist you with any matter; from issues with coworkers to requesting a raise (especially when you have done all the work for your department while your coworker basks in the glory). It's very frustrating when the policy is no more than 3 unexcused absences in a year and your coworker has 19 and your manager does nothing and HR does nothing. 
 When your department has a Code Blue and you have 2 department heads come down from other departments but the manager of your own department doesn't, that tells me whatever that manager has going on is way more important than this patient in distress. Then my favorite is you have all of your phlebotomists call in sick except for 1 and you have 1 front desk person for check in for 13 hours and your manager doesn't even come down to see if the two staff members need anything, water, coffee, a break, lunch. The supply clerk bought snacks and drinks for us. Be very cautious. The turn over is extremely alarming. It starts at the very top, if they cannot follow the rules themselves and make exceptions for a few rather than all then they should not be in management.

pros: Our patients are the BEST and great Co workers
cons: Administration to heavy with MBA’s and little healthcare experience

review_title: Decent company but a lot of rigid policies to follow

review_title: Think twice before accepting a job here if you are female, older, a minority, or a protected worker class
job_title: Patient Service Representative in Weston, WI
pros: Workers are talented and skilled despite the best efforts of management, upper management, and HR
cons: Favoritism by department managers for their friends; lack of diversity and inclusion; clear violations of federal law and corporate policies; HR management is untrustworthy and does not value contributions of its female professional employees; rampant sexism/racism/ageism in management and HR. Accomplishments of white men are respected and celebrated while accomplishments of minorities are swept under the rug. If you are a woman and speak up about any of these issues then YOU are somehow the problem. In conclusion- if you are a white male and against diversity you will love this place. If you are a minority run away from this place as fast as you can and don’t look back!!!

pros:
Amazing team of coworkers, it truly feels like a family
Lots of ancillary staff help and hardworking CNAs
cons:
The main Marshfield hospital is a lot larger and has higher acuity than the other Marshfield hospitals. Upper management doesn't seem to acknowledge this and staffing ratios are slipping into dangerous territory. It's worse than during covid because at least they were paying people to come help. 
No improvement in wages or working conditions for ancillary staff. This pro is slipping away because often there is no unit clerk, no transport, one phlebotomist that is in a code so you can't get your labs drawn. People can get better pay with with less stress elsewhere so they are leaving in droves . Don't blame them but the remaining staff are made to pick up the slack and treated poorly when they can't manage the work of 5 people

review_title: Poor leadership, poor pay, poor benefits, poor culture
pros: Struggling to think of any. Some of my colleagues were decent, but they were in the minority. Work/life balance was okay only because they absolutely did not want to pay for overtime.
cons: Pay, benefits, cliquey atmosphere, poor morale, leadership, overall business model.

pros: Monday through Friday work week with no holidays
cons: Place a lot of work on managers. No work-life balance. Extra hours on nights and weekends just to keep up.

pros: ability to be creative in food prep, 2nd shift, great team
cons: no incentive, lacks compensation for its backbone, free for all in standard precautions protocols-priorities all wrong....

review_title: Do not consider working here, if you do leave now.
pros: There are no reasons someone should work here. Management is toxic, people are treated horribly.
cons: Management is not held to any ethical standards.  Supervisors  often have no experience performing the departments they oversee, they are promoted based on blind loyalty and willingness to mistreat subordinates. This dynamic  has resulted in a terrible work environment, awful employee satisfaction surveys and an inability to hire qualified staff and providers.  Providers are leaving regularly and are not being replaced.  Sadly, it has become apparent that protecting poor leaders is more important than the success of the organization.  Inability to successfully recruit providers has lead to poor patient experience. Sadly, recruitment efforts are falling short with regard to providers.

pros: The patients are the only good thing
cons: Discrimination, lies, under appreciated, bullying. The Marshfield clinic truly is as awful as people say. Took me 5 years to figure that out. Glad it wasn’t 6 years. Don’t waste your time. Unless you like working for a company where truthfully all they care about is money. They tell the doctors to spend less time with patients (so they can see more in a day=more money). They allow bullying and harassment. They try to act like they’re “family oriented” but when it comes down to it, you don’t matter and everyone is “replaceable”. Hence the 500+ open positions in the Marshfield center alone. Awful atmosphere and awful culture

job_title: Data Entry in Rice Lake, WI
pros: The patients and my coworkers were the pros
cons: Marshfield is not employee friendly; I was working for RCMH (Rusk County Memorial Hospital) when it was sold to Marshfield by the county. Marshfield promised to keep all former RCMH employees and the wages we were making; Marshfield made our jobs a living hell to get us former RCMH employees to quit so they wouldn't have to keep us at our current wages. Marshfield only cares about the bottom line; the docs they have are good, but they are limited in what they can and cannot do. Not a nice place!

job_title: Senior Learning Analyst in Eau Claire, WI
pros: People who work there really care for the patients and patient experience.
cons: Old culture has carried over that salaried IS employees expected to work 45+ hours consistently, and outside employees working hours with no comp time. Most also have to be on-call. On-call pay starts is only for 12 hours yet on-call lasts for 15. Learning analysts, salaried, are expected to provide support that could and should be handled by other teams that are hourly, which translates to cheap labor. New Learning Analysts, based on market compensation analysis, make more coming in then those working many years. The compensation is not adjusted for seasoned employees based on market analysis.

review_title: Worked at Ladysmith, Rice Lake, and two other small sites in the system.
pros: I liked the benefits offered and the diversity of the patients. Every year the benefits did decrease.
cons: Many of the co-workers (mainly the MA's) at the Rice Lake and especially the Ladysmith center were constantly trying to back stab each other. They were cruel to each other and would lie about serious issues to the point of an employee loosing their job. It was not uncommon to see a co-worker in tears. The management team in Ladysmith constantly lied to the employees. They also preached customer service but when employees tried to deliver it to the customers they were looked down upon by management. This company is a good example of why unions should return. Extremely stressful work environment for good employees trying to serve the public.

review_title: Abandon all hope, ye who enter here
pros: Good benefits, standard hours (in the department I was in, anyway.) Job security since they hire too few people for the amount of work.
cons: The department I worked in at the Clinic was the most dysfunctional organization I have ever seen. Management had absolutely no clue what was going on; they gave you more and more responsibilities and then couldn't understand why everything wasn't done on time with a nice pretty ribbon on it. They would ignore the 99.9% of the good work you did and rake you over the coals for the .1% you got wrong. Way, way too much work for the number of staff, which was compounded by giving different work to one extremely difficult employee who felt they shouldn't have to do the job they were hired for. Ironic that working for a health care provider probably took years off of my life. Plus the Clinic is constantly complaining about budget woes but every week they announce they're building another new facility or buying an existing one.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Wausau, WI
pros: I enjoy the people I work with. The provider I work for is wonderful as well. For my position outreach is no more than 40 miles away.
cons: Not enough time to get all your work done. Short staffed. Busy clinic and note having time to triage phone calls and call patient's back in a timely fashion. If you would take a call it put's the provider behind and unhappy patient's in the waiting room. In the middle of rooming patient's, set up surgery and go over surgery booklet and sign consent in a hurry. With the new insurance changes it now adds more work with little time. Multiple triage forms to put into prior authorization in a timely fashion. Some other coworkers are favored and have a easier work load due to extra help with a triage nurse. Yes, even though we are in the same department.

review_title: The work is rewarding, the hours and salary are fair.  Opportunities for programmer advancement does not exist.
pros: Rewarding work to improve patient care, it is the mission of the organization and they mean it.  Overall get to work with friendly and helpful people.  Stable job with low rate of turnover.  Working remotely has recently became more available.
cons: Location, to really advance you have to be in Marshfield which is not a place many spouses want to live.  Confused direction, to many upper level managers whose responsibilities are clear, which can also put programmers in the middle.  Salary structures we changed from several tiers to only a couple which has created unfair salary disparities.

pros: Great benefits if you were hired before they were taken away.
cons:
Due to massive reorganization and the cancellation of the main project most of the talent is fleeing the company or already gone

Retirement benefits for recent hires and future employees was slashed from 11% to 3% (thousands of dollars).

There doesn't appear to be meaningful projects coming for the forseeable future 

Favoritism. Meaningful work is hoarded by senior employees or handed to select individuals making it extremely difficult to feel a sense of ownership or pride. 

Leadership is not transparent

Your future isn't decided with you in the room

Low morale 

No vision

Leadership makes jokes about everyone quitting

Anti young professional..MCIS leader makes mean comments about how millennials may have children and are therefore not as valuable to the company because having a life would cost too much

Marshfield

review_title: A small town with small town politics in the workplace aspiring to be a world class I.S. organization
pros: Excellent selection of technologies in the infrastructure space.  A willingness now to look at accountability when it come to chargeback, budgeting and the cost of I.T. investments and how it may affect the bottom line.
cons: Unable to commit to complete essentials required to support and operationalize the technologies that are in use.  Exceedingly "mom and pop" arrangement with respect to capital budgeting and chargeback.  Very little communication on architectural direction and the desired implementation.

pros: The best part about working at Marshfield Clinic and MCIS is that if you want to live in a small city in the middle of no where, it is really the only place to work as a professional.
cons: Leadership is horrible.  No one is empowered to make decisions.  If you are not one of the favorites, you are no one and you can't get anywhere in the organization.  Leadership has no conceptual understanding of the reality they are living in.  They don't know how to deliver software and solutions in a timely manner.  If there was a fundamental change in leadership, they might have a chance.

review_title: The only place I worked that was worse was McDonalds
pros: friendly and courteous nurses and staff
cons: bullying, nepotism, poor communication, terrible management, financial insolvency, benefits cuts, wage cuts, vindictive management, culture of lying, location

pros:
The place is working hard to play catchup after doing nothing for 10 or more years. 
A few years ago we finally got a CEO that seems to care about all the people not just the doctors. 
The patient is the focus 
There are good benefits along with nice clinics and building more and now building hospitals. 
Lots of chance to move around and learn more
cons:
The catchup means it seems kind of crazy sometimes. That can be exciting and sometimes they just need to share more information 
There are still some bullies but some have left or been pushed out. Hopefully more will leave

pros: Co-workers are great. Always willing to help each other out.
cons: Too many to list. Administration is way too heavy now--positions have been created that are overpaid and ridiculous. Over last several years clinic has taken turn for the worst. Buying up hospitals they can't afford and are not experienced to run, while outsourcing everything in order to save money. Benefits and little perks for staff are now horrible, from a clinic that used to care about its employees and treated them well...again this was up until Dr. Turney took over. They don't do what is in best interest of patients, they do what is best for their own pocketbook.

review_title: MCIS is not the amazing start-up they think they are.
pros: Benefits are good.  These were carried over from the parent company, Marshfield Clinic.  Vacation policy is generous.  Flexible work schedules are nice.
cons: Leadership in MCIS is lacking.  The CIO and senior leadership tell people what they want to hear, not what they can actually deliver.  Many people resigned in the the last year because of lack of confidence in leadership, and the toxic work environment.  There is constant churning with re-orgs and changing technologies so that little has been delivered in the past 3 years.

pros:
o Working in research brings a wide variety of experiences and responsibilities.
o Leadership who know you by name and genuinely care about your career.
o Pay is on par with most organizations in the surrounding area.
o Meaningful work.
cons:
o No matter how well research does and how much funding we bring in per year, we are at the mercy of how well patient-care does across the clinic.
o Pay raises are few and far between.
o Need better career ladders for some positions to encourage retention.

review_title: Most physicians who've written reviews need to find out how bad things are in much of the rest of the country.
pros: While not the highest compensation in the midwest, you are protected from much of the painful hassles existing in most small clinic operations that exist in most of the country. Also, compensation is considerably more than in an academic center or on the west coast. Benefits during my employment were excellent, but appear to have settled into the ordinary range, except to note that Marshfield still has a defined contribution retirement plan, _in_addition_ to the 401k. Time off is more than reasonable and CME benefits are far more than most other clinics. Finally, while it may seem like the electronic medical record will take over your life, it actually works as advertised, which is more than I can say for most 'certified' systems.
cons: I think others have summed this up nicely. If you 'fit', you'll do very well. If you want everything to be your way, you'll struggle - to be efficient, there has to be some uniformity. Many of the patients are spoiled, and imagine they could get the same level of care anywhere. Despite some of the micromanagement concerns, some longtime physicians seem to flout the rules. And corporate counsel are extremely risk averse, but I honestly miss the deliberative approach not that I've seen how willy-nilly delicate issues are managed elsewhere. While the salary setting process for physicians seems excessively labor intensive and detailed (described elsewhere), it is largely in response to physician demand. Some managers have never worked outside the system and have a very limited imagination.

review_title: Cultural changes endanger large multispecialty clinic
pros: Marshfield Clinic is a not for profit large multispecialty clinic that provides generally high quality care for patient in large parts of central and northern Wisconsin through a large main clinic with a number of satellites and regional centers. MC provides most of the charity care for this region, and patients are not turned away for financial reasons. Currently MC is in the process of changing governance structures because of changing IRS requirements for non-profit organizations in a manner that appears to maintain as much physician input as possible for a traditionally physician-run organization.
cons:
The current administration attempted to push through a plan for the governance change that had not been adequately vetted by the current board of directors. MC has doubled in size over the past 20 years, and there has been an associated huge increase in management positions, most of which do not directly answer to physician supervision. At all levels we have disconnections between the care we try to provide and the management structure. For instance we have odd situations like the inability to make changes in the letters we send to patients when they receive an appointment or to change the staff process for making appointments because physicians cannot get the attention of middle level managers, and middle level managers have no real authority. Physicians are leaving at a rate never seen before (in the past stability of physician pool has been high) as production pressures increase and increased production requirements serve as a mechanism to cut salaries. Thus physicians are under intense production pressure with a management that is self-maintaining and apparently incapable of addressing core inefficiencies.

There are droves of attorneys in management positions, in my view an important cause of a change in culture over the past ten years from one in which physician voices were heard and respected to one in which physicians and other employees are treated with equal disrespect and disregard for their work environment and the role the work environment plays in overall quality of life. The physician and non-physician management operate in a rigidly rule-bound manner that shows little regard for the impact that unpredictable life events may have on a person's work life.

review_title: Advanced technologies, heavy workload, some weak team members.
pros:
-Mostly fair compensation for the area.
-Great technologies for IT professionals looking to boost their resume.
-Many good IT staff members.
-Feels good to provide IT to better and support patient care.
cons:
-Heavy workload due to short IT staffing.
-Morale low because of workload for some.
-Poor performers are shuffled around and tolerated while good performers pick up their slack which is frustrating.
-Requirements for upper level IT jobs too strict for the area.

review_title: Enjoyed the work and most of my coworkers in the Center for Community Outreach. Management lacked communication skills.
pros:
- Coworkers were very friendly
- Does a lot of good work in the community
cons:
- Management lacks communication skills
- Policies inconsistently applied
- No room for advancement

review_title: Decent company for a small town, but the future doesn't look that bright for the company.
pros: For a company that doesn't have a lot of competition in the immediate area, they have maintained competitive salaries. However, I'm seeing that rapidly crumble, so I'm not sure how long that will be correct.
cons: Training for my position was non-existent. People who have close relationships with management or complain the most get promoted regardless of work ethics and quality of work. Insurance benefits used to be decent, but for 2015 are pretty bad.

review_title: Easy pace of work, risk-averse management, and small-town mentality.
pros: Good work-life balance. The work atmosphere is very relaxed with hardly any strict deadlines. You work at your own pace. Most people are from small towns around Wisconsin and are used to the easy pace of things. Good place to be if you can fit into that mindset. Compensation is not the greatest, but then again everything in Marshfield is cheap, so you don't need that much anyway. 21 days of PTO to start with is pretty decent. Coworkers are very respectful. Physical conditions at workplace are very good. It's surprising that such a state of the art facility in small-town Wisconsin. Top-down communication is very good, and it's very easy to get access to top management. Marshfield is a small town, very safe, no traffic, friendly people.
cons:
Senior management is very respectful and treat the employees as humans, but will not let you grow as a professional (probably because they feel threatened). Promotions are mostly based on seniority and not ability. So even if you are really good at what you do and qualified for the next level, you still have to wait in queue till the person who joined before you gets promoted first. Annual raises are a joke (they don't even cover inflation), and there are no performance bonuses. Not a lot of emphasis is given to professional development, or continuing education. They do not help with tuition, or provide any encouragement if you want to develop professionally on your own. Small town mentality means that they are very risk averse, and this shows in the decades old technology that they still use. Some people I worked with found it difficult to move horizontally into other areas within IT/IS, as such a move is not encouraged. In fact, some senior management will try to stifle such attempts.

Marshfield is a town of 20000 people or so, in the middle of farmland Wisconsin; make sure you are aware of that before you start at Marshfield Clinic. There is absolutely nothing to do there in terms of entertainment (unless you like to spend your evenings at hick country bars). There are no other significant towns around, the biggest city is Madison about 2 and a half hours away.

pros: Excellent insurance benefits, can't be beat the medical benefits if you are ok seeing Marshfield Clinic medical providers.  Good retirment benefit after two years.  Fairly good PTO policy.
cons: Wages freezes.  Some managers are not friendly at all.  Not sure how they ever became managers.  What is the point of opinion surveys if nothing changes.

job_title: IS Project Manager in Marshfield, WI
pros: Great benefits, good work-life balance, challenging meaningful work, intelligent collegues
cons: Politics are as bad as it gets, little room for advancement, salaries are on the lower spectrum of Healthcare IT,

pros: Reasonable benefits and pay as cost of living is low
cons: does not provide an environment that is equitable. Preferential treatment given to staff who play the good old boys game well. Really difficult to stand up for what you feel is right. Even managers are beat up when they try to back their employees.

review_title: A decent place to work, a few weird rules, but I would love to work here again someday.
pros: Good training, good people (sometimes), decent starting wages, allow you to earn PTO on a regular basis.
cons: Communication is lost, people are "clique-y", you can earn PTO, but they don't like to give you the days off you asked for, don't like unpaid time, meaning, you can't call in if you are sick and have no PTO.

pros:
+ large growth opportunities if you're not technical
+ if you are a contractor, you will be able to make substantial money here in the near future
cons:
- System is going through a replatforming
- Ancient leadership with adversity to change and new technology
- Lack of strong leadership
- Reduction in staff likely coming
- If you want to make a difference using your technical skill set, go to another organization

review_title: Shine? They don't know   it from Shinola!
pros: The staff are great.  Sadly, they are overworked, under appreciated, and poorly utilized by management.
cons:
Took this job right out of fellowship and worked there for almost 4 years.  Honestly, the best decision I made about this place was to leave.  

There is too much micromanagement from the top down.  Middle managers and administrators make EVERYTHING a battle.  This all comes down to the "old boy" network and bullying culture promoted by the system.  

Also, because service waits are long, customer service poor, and the location inconvenient, Marshfield Clinic has ceded A LOT of ground/market share to Aspirus and their other competitors in Wausau. This has resulted in a poor payer mix and increasingly non-compliant, entitled, and difficult patients.  Meaning you're often finding yourself fighting an uphill battle on the patient care front, as well.

Physician/provider burn-out rates here were abnormally high to begin with and only got worse as Marshfield Clinic sunk further and further into financial strain and insolvency.  Retention is exceedingly poor and getting worse year after year.  Most providers were looking for new jobs when I was there and many have left in the time since my departure.  Those that remain are merely getting their ducks lined in a row before announcing their intent to leave for better, more stable work environments.

Another problem is they can't be trusted to hold true to the terms of a salary agreement.  This means that the negotiated production rate/RVU basis that you've negotiated for the upcoming year can NEVER be counted on to be what you actually receive.  Invariably, well after the fact, changes are unilaterally made in favor of the Marshfield Clinic.  What this means for providers is that they are working harder and harder, and while they generate more revenue for the Marshfield Clinic, they are taking home less for themselves.  This also contributes significantly to the high provider burn out rate and also means that you're seeing so many patients that patient care suffers.

Finally, the computer record system here, which was state of the art in 1997, hasn't kept pace with technologic advancement.  It's the EHR equivalent of being an AOL user in 2014.  Because MCIS is so poorly managed and run, they will never be able to catch up or keep pace with the advances and changes that are necessary to put together an efficient and facile EHR product.

pros: The people are awsome. Great work ethic for 99% of the non-physician staff.
cons: Physicians tend to feel entitled yet not engaged in the organization and/or culture. Management of the organization is poor as a result of the governance model where too many physicians can impede growth or process improvement.

review_title: Great company to grow and learn with
job_title: Financial Services Representative in Chippewa Falls, WI
pros:
Great company to grow and learn with. 
Marshfield is for someone who is looking for a career and willing to do great things for the community. If money is not an option it's an excellent company as they are flexible with work schedules and encourage ideas and forward thinking.
cons: Low pay, high work, and high turn over in business office.

review_title: Average healthcare facility with little respect for employees.
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Marshfield, WI
pros: This clinic hired me right out of college even though I had no experience. They spent a lot of time and money training me in, which I appreciated.
cons: The clinic will never support you if you are injured or sick or if unforeseen circumstances interfere with work. They paid so low as to be off the bell curve for my position. They do nothing to promote the professional growth of employees. Everything is about money, not the patient.

job_title: Medical Transcriptionist in Eau Claire, WI
pros: Pay, benefits, work from home
cons: Towards the end of my employment there, they really started increasing the productivity requirements, making it nearly impossible for us to meet their demands. I really enjoyed it until they started that. They also would have mandatory overtime and it really started to wear me out. Sometimes they wouldn't tell you about the mandatory OT until Wednesday and would say you would need to do 10 hours or mandatory OT by Friday at 12 a.m.

review_title: A place to work on interesting health care related problems.
pros: Flexible, great people, benefits you have available are great, ability to work remote, getting to be able to affect people's lives in a positive way rather then just out to make money, continues to be a leader and innovator of healthcare IT
cons: Changes in structure, difficulty to change expectations in a large organization, potential for being on a similar project area for extended periods of time

pros: Worked with people who genuinely cared about the quality of work they did.  Marshfield is a nice place to live if you enjoy small town life. Good benefits, fair PTO policy.
cons: Extreme bullying by management and senior staff, no help from HR. Office discipline not consistently imposed, favoritism is common. Very high stress workplace. Terrible pay rate!!!!!

pros: Dedication to excellence in patient care, research and education, benefits are the best I've ever seen, good people to work with, continuing education supported
cons: Leadership is shared among all physicians so changes are slow as seems to be the case in many large corporations.

job_title: Certified Medi in Eau Claire, WI
pros: More than half of the staff are friendly.
cons: Its a factory. Things must go quickly - the more patients they can squeeze into a day the more money they collect.  Its a race that works if you can do the work of 1.5 people for maximum profit.

pros:
-Some great people to work with.
-Physicians who care about patients.
-Low cost of living.
-Decent salary.
-Good retirement plan.
cons:
-This was my fist position after residency.  What a mistake!!

-The city is ok.  It is isolated from large urban areas as it is in rural WI, but that was not what made my time with MC unbearable.

-The staff, for the most part, is very friendly.  However, there were a significant number of MAs and RNs who made life a nightmare for physicians and other staff.  Their attitude was dismal and their respect for patients and HIPPA non-existent.  Many times I found them discussing protected health information between themselves while at lunch in a public location.  Even after I informed the clinic management, nothing was done about it.  This is unacceptable.

-The management is utterly useless.  Concerns are not handled in a confidential manner and no results/consequences are ever discussed.  In fact, decisions are made behind closed doors by HR, management and lawyers for the company before the employee is even aware that there is any type of complaint against them.  The employee is not contacted or has a chance to give his/her side of the story at all.  Once the decision is made, he/she is told of the results.  Not  good for morale.

-Clinic morale was at a low during this past year.  There were numerous staff cuts (which were not disclosed to staff until after it was printed in a local newspaper) to different departments which made things worse in regards to clinic flow during the day.  Many times I had to share a MA during the day with another physician.  Poor girl was running around like a mad woman trying to juggle 4 exam rooms.  

-Division medical directors (DMDs) are out of touch with the physicians who are actually working with patients.  They have no idea what their long term goals are.  They spend an enormous amount of time micromanaging and focusing on minutia that they miss the forest for the trees.  The amount of time spent on salary discussions for individual physicians is ridiculous.  They are unwilling to meet personally, instead choosing to deal mostly via email.  In fact, a lot of the time, phone calls and messages go unanswered for weeks.

-Once again, DMDs only inform the employees of decisions once they have been made, usually by email, even if it is bad news.  No one is willing to speak face to face.

-DMDs do not want you to develop your own plan for your professional development. Since they themselves do not know what they want, they can't tolerate providers making decisions about how to expand and grow their practice.  You ideas will be dismissed.

-Others have talked about a bullying culture at this organizations.  This is true. Not only does it happen from the top down, but also amongst the same level employees. The best performers are only rewarded with more work, not promotions or wage increase and those people who are mediocre  at their job are often  promoted due to their seniority in the organization.

-The situation has gotten so bad, that numerous physicians have left within the past year, with me being one of them.  The smaller centers have almost no specialty coverage and a lot of the ones they had, are now gone.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Rice Lake, WI
pros: Managers are as flexible as they can be. Health benefits are competitive. 401k contributions are competitive. Pay is competitive.
cons: They have become very corporate. It's often unclear on what to report and to whom. Streamlining departments and cutting staff is making for stress and overwork for the current employees.

job_title: IT Support Technician in Eau Claire, WI
pros: None I can think of
cons:
They are more worried about money than anything else.

They cannot keep staff. This was heard everywhere. They were laying off people left and right due to money issues. Cutting wages and benefits.

Staff are treated poorly; I worked in IT. My beginning training was reformatting computers and cleaning them. I received no training on how to do other things like off-network software, their proprietary software, or things like that. I was on the job one week when my co-worker went on vacation...and I still didn't have training on certain things I needed to know.

Trainers wouldn't show up for the training and supervisors woudn't be there for scheduled meetings.

Due to declining health I requested to not be on-call, which was granted. A short time later we were told we all had to have our work phones on us at all times, and turned on, just in case. But they wouldn't pay for us being permanently on-call. And if you got a call, and explained you weren't on-call, you got in trouble for it.

They don't care about their employees, just the bottom line.

They feel they're above the law and don't care.

Avoid this place unless you want to get sick to your stomach each time you think about work.

Burn out rates are very high

review_title: Get out while you still can
job_title: Health Unit Coordinator in Marshfield, WI
pros: Have worked with excellent employees and physicians over the years on the hospital side.
cons: Upper management is in over their heads. No idea how to run a hospital and are focused on buying and building new hospitals instead of the mess they are turning their flagship hospital into. Hemorrhaging staff and physicians and barely recruiting or working on retainment. Morale is terrible and more than half of my co-workers are actively looking for other jobs or are contemplating leaving.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Wausau, WI
pros: Week day hours.  Tend to be done on time.  Co-workers are great people.
cons: Poor compensation. working short staffed often, can't get vacation time or days off.

The break room is also smaller than a patient room for an entire floor of the hospital.
